Ad for a class next semester: 6.Spring 20194, Open Source Software Project Lab

If you enjoyed building real applications in 6.170, then you might also want to look into the latest iteration of a rather new MIT class that connects students with real open-source projects. The announcement says the deadline for announcing interest is yesterday, but probably there's still a chance to get in.

6.Spring 20194 Open Source Software Project Lab, a Lab - based class in large - scale software development, will be offered in the Spring.  In this class, the students will be joining an international team coming from universities such as Stanford, U. of Tokyo, U. of Singapore, U. of Helsinki etc. Each team will be embedded with a prominent open source project (see http://tinyurl.com/6S194projects for next semester's projects) and your grade will be based on your contribution to the project.  Teams will be mentored by leaders from their open source project.  In 6.Spring 20194, you will learn about project management, how to extend and debug unfamiliar systems, coordinate a distributed team, use modern tools, apply open source as a business model.     Because this course is a global collaboration, we need to start forming the teams by early next week. We need to hear from you by 11:59PM on Sunday December 21st  ***THIS SUNDAY***.  The enrollment is limited, apply at http://tinyurl.com/6S194application.  As this class gets heavily oversubscribed, apply only if you are fully committed to take the class.

6.170 Software Studio
Course»Course 6»Fall 2014»6.170
General Information
Background

This is a class in software engineering, with an emphasis on design. It focuses on building web applications and services because of their prominence today. Not every software system is a web app, but the lessons learned in this class apply more broadly.

The class emphasizes how to write modular and elegant code, and how to design an application. Design means clarifying goals, inventing key concepts, and choosing how the application should behave, in addition to structuring the internals. In our experience, these external aspects of design are the most important, the least well understood by MIT students, and the ones that are hardest to acquire in most industrial settings.

Focusing on some aspects inevitably means deemphasizing others. So while the class will teach the fundamentals of web application architecture, and you will become proficient with a particular collection of technologies, these technologies are not the subject of the class. Likewise, quality assurance techniques, such as code review, testing and verification, are not extensively covered.
Objectives
By the end of this class, you will have developed skills in four distinct competency areas:
Hacking:

being able to build a working web application, which involves: writing code fluently in several languages (eg, JavaScript, HTML and CSS); becoming familiar and comfortable with using libraries (such as JQuery), web frameworks (such as Node and Express), databases (such as MongoDB) and browser tools (such as the Chrome IDE); working with GitHub repositories.
Robust coding:

writing code that is well organized at a high level; exploiting the best programming language features appropriately and avoiding troublesome ones; applying sophisticated idioms (such as functionals and closures) to structure code elegantly; using modularization features to encapsulate data representations and other design secrets, and to minimize repetition; defining clean interfaces to decouple components; preventing security attacks by using standard mitigations; including automatable unit tests in the code base; writing succinct and helpful specifications; choosing names and commenting judiciously.
Design:

analyzing problems to understand what the tricky aspects are; focusing and prioritizing the goals of a software project; constructing a conceptual design for a system that identifies the key concepts and their relationships; developing an interaction design using wireframes; identifying key design issues, and analyzing their tradeoffs; selecting features for a minimal viable product; designing a data model and transforming it into a database schema.
Professionalism:

constructing and delivering a slide presentation on your work; collaborating with team members; making constructive critiques of other students' work; ensuring a polished visual appearance and clear organization in written work, slides and deployed software.
Textbooks
There is no required text. Here are some books that provide useful background on JavaScript and node.js:
Douglas Crockford. JavaScript: The Good Parts ($17)
Stoyan Stefanov. JavaScript Patterns ($20)
Michael Mikowski. Single Page Web Applications: JavaScript end-to-end ($41)
John Resig. Secrets of the JavaScript Ninja ($26)
Jim R. Wilson. Node.js the Right Way: Practical, Server-Side JavaScript That Scales ($14)
Mike Cantelon. Node.js in Action ($27)
Course Structure
Projects:

. There are weekly assignments for the first half of term, grouped into four separate projects, of which the first three are solo and the last is a team project. The second half of term is spent on a larger team project. Teams will generally have four members; you will be able to choose your teammates, but may not work with the same teammate on both projects.
Repositories:

. You'll keep all your work in a GitHub repository, and you will receive grading comments from your TAs on GitHub too. You are responsible for obtaining your own repository. Free repositories are public by default. If you prefer to make your repository private, you will need to pay the fee for an upgrade.
Lectures:
. There are two 80-minute lectures each week, which will focus on fundamental concepts and exemplars.
Quizzes:

. After each segment of the course (typically lasting a week or two) there will be a short in-class quiz consisting of around five multiple choice questions to test your understanding of the lecture material.
Recitations:

. Each student will attend one 50-minute recitation each week. Recitations are taught by teaching assistants and focus on the basics of the various technologies you will be using. You can choose which recitation to attend, and may attend a different one each week.
Office hours and labs:

. The TAs will be available for office hours and lab hours each week at times that will be posted on the Stellar front page. These are likely to change in response to student demand, so be sure to check when you make your plans for the week. Office hours are intended for students who have a particular topic they want to discuss with a TA; labs are intended to provide a place where several students and TAs will be working so that you can get help as you need it. Labs will likely be phased out as the term progresses once students become familiar with the key technologies.
Collaboration and Grading Policy
Individual projects:

. Your work on the solo projects should be entirely your own, although you are encouraged to ask TAs for advice in lab sessions and office hours, and to use Piazza to obtain answers to questions from other students. This policy is designed to ensure that all students come to grips with the basic languages and technologies that they will need throughout the course.
Team projects:

. Team projects, of course, encourage collaboration. You are encouraged to work together on all aspects of the projects; you should ensure that every team member is involved in all aspects of the project (design, coding and documentation).
Reuse of third-party material:

. You are free to use any third-party code, whether as libraries or code fragments, and to adopt any ideas you find online or in books, so long as it is publicly available and appropriately cited (see the section on code in the MIT handbook on academic integrity for details). You may not use work produced by students in earlier offerings of this class. Obviously, you may not reuse a complete solution to a project.
Sanctions:
. If you violate the course collaboration policy, for example by collaborating outside lab sessions on individual projects, you can expect to be asked to drop the class (or worse).
Grading:

. Components of the class will be weighted as follows: solo projects 30%, small team project 20%, final project 35%, quizzes 10%, participation 5%. The participation grade is a determined subjectively by the staff observing your interactions in lecture, recitation and team mentoring sessions, and your contributions to online forums such as Piazza. Your lowest quiz grade will be dropped. For the assignments, the four competency areas described above will account for these proportions of your grade: hacking 30%, robust coding 30%, design 30%, professionalism 10%.
Lateness:

. Each student has four slack days that can be distributed throughout the solo projects in any way. Slack days may not be used for team projects. For each day that an assignment is handed in late without a slack day, 10% of the total assignment value is lost. Missed quizzes cannot be made up. Extensions without penalty are given for (a) major illness, and (b) other extraordinary circumstances; in both cases, a letter from a doctor or dean is required. Note that trips, interviews, minor illness, etc., are not grounds for extensions: this is what slack days are for.
Class Contract
The teaching staff of the course will endeavor to:
Deliver content that is stimulating, practically useful and of long-term intellectual value;
Encourage interaction during all class and recitation sections, and take all questions seriously;
Provide constructive and helpful feedback on student work in a timely fashion;
Assign grades in a fair and consistent way;
Take seriously suggestions about course content and structure;
Help students who feel overwhelmed or lacking in background, despite prerequisites;
Support and encourage full participation of all students.
As a student, by taking this course, you agree to endeavor to:
Attend all class sessions, and to participate enthusiastically;
Not use laptops and mobile devices during class, except when asked to do exercises that require them;
Share concerns and comments about the course with the lecturers;
Do your fair share of work on your team project.
Advice
Open-ended projects.:

In each of the small projects (prior to the final project), you'll be given an outline of a problem to solve. In contrast to many of the assignments you'll have done at MIT, these will not be precisely specified. It'll be your job to figure out exactly what the problem is! This is one of the most important things to learn in being any kind of designer. You should take this aspect very seriously, not only because it's important and fun, but also because you'll save yourself a lot of time and effort if you know what the problem is before you start trying to solve it.
Getting started early.:

We strongly recommend that you get going on projects as soon as you can, so you can get help from the teaching staff and from your colleagues using the Piazza forum, and make good use of lab and office hours. A good practice is to make a start early in the week, giving the project enough time to give you a sense of what's involved and how much work it's likely to be. Whatever you do, don't leave work until the night of the deadline!
Professionalism.:

Part of being professional is presenting your work well. Use this class as an opportunity to practice presenting your design and implementation work in a professional way. So make sure your diagrams are neat; your writing is succinct and grammatical; your text documents show good typographic taste; your user interfaces are clean and stylish; and so on. Also think about how your TA will encounter your work: is it organized in the right way, following class guidelines, so that it's accessible and clear where everything is?
Attending class.:

Every term, some number of students skip class. You should realize that these are typically the weaker students, and they tend to perform more poorly. If you don't find class helpful, let us know why and we'll try and address your concerns.
Questions?

Questions that might be of interest to other students should be posted in the online forum. Personal questions should be sent to 6170-staff at mit.edu. You can also contact the assistants or lecturers directly using 6170-ta and 6170-lec.
